page.title: 03STREET END ESTATE
page.content: The Baker-White family purchased Street End Estate in 1860. The 1500 acres of farms, woods and parkland are now run as a family business. The first Street End Place, built in 1700 fell into disrepair. It was demolished in 1962 and replaced the following year by a one-storey residence. The Coach House and buildings, with a wall of mathematical tiles, stables and laundry still remain. The Coach House, now the Estate Office, was the Home Guard Headquarters in the 1939-45 war. Behind the new Street End Place is the old walled garden with a 200 year old mulberry tree. Part of the sundial is from the original church, rebuilt in 1832. The gardens and grounds are open to the public once a year in the Spring. The Estate owns the forge, Forge Cottage and several dwellings in the village.
